DOC.HEAD: China Welcomes U.S. Decision on Satellites
DOC.TEXT: China on Thursday praised President Bush for easing economic sanctions, saying the measures would help restore normal relations. Bush's actions were ``positive steps helpful to the normalization of relations between China and the United States,'' said Foreign Ministry spokesman Jin Guihua. ``We welcome this.'' Bush this week exempted from economic sanctions the export of three communications satellites to be launched by China and sanctioned Export-Import Bank credit to companies doing business in China. The relaxation of sanctions followed a Dec. 9-10 visit to Beijing by National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft that ended a U.S. ban on high-level exchanges between the two sides. The Bush administration, which imposed the sanctions after the bloody military attack on student-led pro-democracy demonstrators this June, has been criticized for being too friendly to Beijing's hard-line leaders. White House officials said the decision to allow China to launch satellites for Australian and Hong Kong firms, and the waiving of restrictions on low-interest Ex-Im Bank loans to Americans investing in China, were in the ``national interest.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the sale of the satellites will bring $300 million worth of business to U.S. firms. Jin declined comment on whether Bush's actions would help settle other outstanding issues, particularly that of Fang Lizhi, the outspoken dissident who has been hiding in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing since June. Jin repeated the Chinese position that Fang's future is a ``sensitive question'' that must be solved through joint efforts of the two sides. Jin also reread a Foreign Ministry statement issued earlier condemning U.S. military action in Panama, saying it was interference in the internal affairs of another country and a violation of international law. On Saturday, a senior Soviet Communist Party official arrives for a visit to include talks between the two largest Marxist nations on the crisis in world communism. The crumbling of one-party Communist rule in Eastern Europe is certain to be on the agenda during the weeklong visit of Valentin Falin, head of the decision-making Central Committee's International Department, a Soviet Embassy official said. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Chinese are unhappy with events in Eastern Europe and are eager to sound out the Soviets on their approach to the popular groundswell of opposition to Communist rule. The official said the Chinese have also expressed concern about growing turmoil in Romania, East Europe's most stubborn holdout against political reform and a staunch ally of China since its military crackdown. On bilateral matters, Falin will discuss how to improve party-to-party relations following the May visit of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, which ended a 30-year freeze in Sino-Soviet party contacts. Falin has asked to meet party General Secretary Jiang Zemin, and a favorable response from the Chinese would indicate their willingness to move party relations to a higher plane, the official said. The two sides may touch on a planned visit by Premier Li Peng to Moscow, tentatively set for next April. The official said overall Sino-Soviet relations have generally progressed well since the Gorbachev visit in spite of the June turmoil in China and divergences in views on political reform. He said there were so many Soviet delegations visiting China that the embassy could no longer handle them all. Trade along the once-tense border is booming, and total bilateral trade is expected to increase substantially from last year's $3.25 billion. The official China Daily said Thursday that the two countries are now discussing cooperation in a $46 million project to build China's first coal slurry pipeline. Soviet officials acknowledge, however, that China's top priority is still obtaining Western technology, and China's strained relations with the West will not result in a sharp increase in Sino-Soviet economic exchanges. The Soviet Union, the official said, hopes better relations with China will facilitate multinational development of Siberia's rich natural resources, with Chinese laborers being brought in for projects backed by Japanese, U.S. and South Korean technology and financing.
